items.title: with terminal.location() works fine with y but not consistently with x
items.body:
Hi there,

First of all, thanks for that lovely module, very nice and useful! 

I found something that is halfway between a bug and a feature request: when invoking `with terminal.location():`, it works really well for the y dimension (the row on which we print), however only the first print statement will be located properly on the x axis (indented, as it were). When working with it I resorted to use only the y dimension, always 0 for x, and manually adding a move in front of my messages, or wrapping each printing statement with the with syntax, but that defeats the purpose a bit. 

Here is a working example:

```
from blessings import Terminal

t = Terminal()
print(t.clear)
with t.location(10, t.height//2):
    print('this is correct')
    print('height is good, but it goes back to the beginning of the line')

print(t.move(t.height))
```

Cheers!
Jeremie

items.title: Terminal not updated
items.body:
I wanted to write a little swirly progress indicator which successively displays |, /, -, and . The following code is an example of what I had in mind:

```
from blessings import Terminal

term = Terminal()
indicators = '|/-\\'
with term.hidden_cursor():
    print('Working'+term.move_x(term.width-1), end='')
    i = 0
    while True:
        print(term.move_left + indicators[i], end='')
        i += 1
        i %= len(indicators)
```

This works well, but if I include a `time.sleep(1)` into the `while`-loop, the line in the terminal remains empty – no swirling indicators and not even the preamble `'Working'`:

```
import time
from blessings import Terminal

term = Terminal()
indicators = '|/-\\'
with term.hidden_cursor():
    print('Working'+term.move_x(term.width-1), end='')
    i = 0
    while True:
        print(term.move_left + indicators[i], end='')
        time.sleep(1)
        i += 1
        i %= len(indicators)
```

I got it working by including the line `sys.stdout.flush()` after the print statement. Is that the correct way to handle this scenario?

Thanks,
Stephan

items.title: Provide wheel package on PyPI
items.body:
Hi!

Please could this package also by made available as a wheel on PyPI?
https://pypi.python.org/pypi/blessings

Wheels have the following advantages:
* Faster installation time
* Allows the wheel cache to work even when using the new pip hash-checking mode
* Allows tools to statically inspect the package metadata without having to execute untrusted code.
* ...and more - see: http://pythonwheels.com

Since this package uses 2to3 on Python 3, it will need to have separate wheels for each, rather than a universal wheel:
https://packaging.python.org/tutorials/distributing-packages/#wheels

The Python packaging guide recommends using [Twine](https://github.com/pypa/twine) to upload packages:
https://packaging.python.org/tutorials/distributing-packages/#uploading-your-project-to-pypi

As such, the steps for building/uploading a new release are then:

```bash
$ pip2 install -U twine setuptools wheel
$ pip3 install -U setuptools wheel
$ rm -rf dist/ build/
$ python2 setup.py sdist bdist_wheel
# Work around https://bitbucket.org/pypa/wheel/issues/147/bdist_wheel-should-start-by-cleaning-up
$ rm -rf build/
$ python3 setup.py bdist_wheel
$ twine upload dist/*
```

The PyPI package listing will then display three entries for the new release, one with type "Source" and two of type "Python Wheel" (one for each of Python 2 and 3).

Many thanks :-)

items.title: move_right(n) is not possible // cuf1 vs cuf
items.body:
While documenting internals, noticed:

`move_right` is sugar for `cuf1`. This means `term.move_right` can move the cursor right one cell (non-destructively).

However, there is no sugar for `cuf`.
This means `term.move_right(20) == term.move_right()`:

```
In [14]: term.move_right(20)
Out[14]: u'\x1b[C'

In [15]: term.move_right
Out[15]: u'\x1b[C'
```

I'd like to think term.move_right(n) and move_left can intelligently chose cuf/cub when n is specified and greater than 1. When 1, cuf1/cub1 should be used.  Otherwise, `''` for 0, or negative values.

items.title: Remove 'interruptable' option.
items.body:
Previously, one always had to deal with InterruptError, as is done in private method `_char_is_ready` (previously, public method `kbhit`).

Beginning in python3.5, interruptions are automatically retried, and such code is not required any longer.

We should follow suite and automatically retry, and remove the toggle option to disable this behavior to match python3.5.  I can't think of any reason why somebody might want `keystroke` (previously, `inkey`) to return earlier than `timeout` specified when no keypress is received.

items.title: Change `__all__` to lists
items.body:
Whoever wrote the pep257 tool was laboring under a misapprehension in this case. Almost all packages use lists for `__all__`, including Sphinx, six, Jinja2, nose, pip, Pygments, and even the examples in https://docs.python.org/2/tutorial/modules.html itself. The pep257 tool is welcome to assume `__all__` is immutable and should do so quietly. It would be exceedingly weird to mutate it and isn't worth a startling warning. Besides, even a tuple `__all__` could be rebound later: it's not like it's `final`.

items.title: Normalize docstring formatting
items.body:
The format favored on master is…

```
"""Return a capability that sets the foreground color.

The capability is unparametrized until called and passed a number
(0-15), at which point it returns another string which represents a
specific color change. This second string can further be called to
color a piece of text and set everything back to normal afterward.

:arg num: The number, 0-15, of the color

"""
```

That's as PEP-257-compliant as practicable, deviating only when the summary line can't fit in 79 cols. Sphinx joins multi-line first lines uneventfully. Note the Sphinx-style `:arg` directives, the trailing blank line inside the quotes as per PEP 257, the triple quotes, and the summary line beginning on the same line as the opening quotes. Symbols referenced within the docstring should be double-tilde-quoted as the contents of the docstring should be ReST.

items.title: Cannot call setupterm() more than once per process
items.body:
Whichever terminal "kind" was used when Terminal() was first instantiated will continue to be used for the remainder of the program, regardless of the value of "kind" argument to subsequent instantiations.

This is because of the curses C api that python hooks through, and some things done in setupterm() that last for the duration of the process.

The correct fix, would be that every time Terminal() is instantiated, a subprocess is spanwed, and termcap translation later requested is piped through it. This is the method that I use, by way that the first Terminal() instantiation occurs in sub-process, and not a thread. This may however be too bloated.

An intermediate fix that I would be happy to patch propose, would be to generate a warning -- if Terminal() is instantiated again, without the same "kind", then a warning is emitted.

$ python3 -c 'import blessings;print(repr(blessings.Terminal(kind="xterm").red_on_black));print(repr(blessings.Terminal(kind="vt220").red_on_black));'
'\x1b[31m\x1b[40m'
'\x1b[31m\x1b[40m'

$ python3 -c 'import blessings;print(repr(blessings.Terminal(kind="vt220").red_on_black));print(repr(blessings.Terminal(kind="xterm").red_on_black));'
''
''

items.title: An idiom for many moves
items.body:
This (seen at https://gist.github.com/1515325) is an antipattern:

```
with self.term.location(x, y):
  print '╔' + '═' * (w - 2) + '╗'
for i in range(h - 2):
  with self.term.location(x, y + i + 1):
    print '║'
  with self.term.location(x + w - 1, y + i + 1):
    print '║'
with self.term.location(x, y + h - 1):
  print '╚' + '═' * (w - 2) + '╝'
```

It's long and does twice as much cursor movement as necessary. I can think of several ways I would refactor to make it more concise, but perhaps that shouldn't be the caller's responsibility. Think about providing a standard concise spelling.

items.title: Make height_and_width not assume stdout
items.body: Grab the fileno off the terminal, like this: http://code.google.com/p/terminal-py/source/browse/trunk/terminal.py#156

items.title: Sugar a few more capabilities
items.body: We're missing a few good ones from http://code.activestate.com/recipes/475116-using-terminfo-for-portable-color-output-cursor-co/?c=13764.

items.title: Change licenses
items.body: Switch to a more permissive license. There's no point requiring GPL-itude for the sake of a lightweight terminal library, and I want maximal uptake. Apache 2 looks like a decent choice—I like its patent language—except that the FSF deems it incompatible with GPLs 1 and 2. (3 is fine.) Perhaps BSD or MIT would minimize barriers to adoption.

items.title: color capability should fall back to setf
items.body: If there's no `setaf` or `setab`, fall back to `setf` and `setb`.

items.title: Avoid reference cycles in Terminal._codes
items.body: FormattingStrings, in particular, keep a ref to the terminal around. We can use weakrefs or, perhaps simpler, resolve references to `term.normal` immediately on construction.

items.title: Hard-code terminal type in tests
items.body: Right now, we're comparing against some known-good results of tigetstr, but those can differ across terminal types. Hard-code whatever my terminal type is in there.

items.title: Optionally ignore tty check
items.body:
It would be great if a kwarg could skip the tty check. Some pipes can still handle output formatting (notably `less -r` or `-R`), so if I wrote a CLI program using blessings to, say, color output, and I wanted to make it possible to pipe that output to `less` in a nice Unixy way, I might add a CL option that I could later pass into the `Terminal()` constructor, e.g.:

``` python
if __name__ == '__main__':
    (opts, args) = parser.parse_args()
    term = Terminal(ignore_tty=opts.R)
    main(term)
```

items.title: Add is_terminal bit
items.body: Add an `is_terminal` attr on `Terminal` that you can check before drawing progress bars and other such things that are interesting only in a terminal context.

items.title: Mnemonic colors
items.body: I can't remember that green is 2. Come up with something. Remember that `setaf` and `setf` take subtly different color mappings, so maybe `term.red` would be a good idea.

items.title: Add more sugary capabilities
items.body: Comb through the terminfo man page for useful capabilities with confounding names, and add sugary attribute names for them.
